When the coronavirus pandemic halted much of the travel industry earlier this year, Carin Kiphart and her husband saw their international tour guide business dry up and largely stay that way.

But the couple's vacation rental on Navarre Beach is another story. Initially shuttered in March, vacation rentals in Florida were allowed to re-open over Memorial Day weekend. Since then, the Kipharts' five-bedroom house on Navarre Beach has been "slammed" all the way through the recent Labor Day weekend.

"It's pretty much our main income now, so we're really glad we made that (income) diversification," Kiphart said Tuesday after the long holiday weekend that marks the unofficial end of summer.

State drop:Florida's tourism suffered an estimated 60.5% drop due to COVID-19 in second quarter

Fifth cent:TDC recommends fifth-cent bed tax to help with tourism recovery from COVID-19

A rebound in short-term vacation rentals has been one of the few bright sports as the local tourism industry recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic.

For the Kipharts, while revenue from their rental isn't as high as it was in 2019, their house has been consistently booked and they're seeing solid bookings during the shoulder season through mid-October.

"People want to get away and be somewhere where they feel safe in a private home," Kiphart said. "We're fortunate that we have a pool and a hot tub so then people also wanted that private pool. That was a big deal for them."

Nicole Stacey, director of marketing and communications for Visit Pensacola, said vacation rentals have seen a strong rebound, perhaps because people feel safer in individual units, rather than ones with shared common spaces like hotels.

That suits areas like Navarre Beach particularly well, which is a primarily vacation rental market with only one hotel on the beach. Santa Rosa County's July bed tax collections were up more than 12% from the previous year, totaling $650,314.58.

"The spring was pretty difficult for us, but once the governor lifted the restrictions and our vacation rentals opened up, we bounded back very quick," said Nicole Dees, tourist development special with the Santa Rosa County Tourist Development Office. "Vacation rentals are the majority of our bed tax collections."

She said four RV parks in Navarre, another source of bed tax dollars for the county, have also been almost fully booked for the entire summer.

The hotel industry, however, hasn't seen the same rebound as vacation rentals, with many hotels reporting shorter average stays and lower rates. But good weather over the long holiday weekend helped give the industry a boost at the end of the traditional summer season.

Ted Ent, CEO and president of Innisfree Hotels, said this Labor Day weekend is difficult to compare to previous Labor Day weekends because recent years have been affected by bad weather. He said occupancy and room rates this holiday weekend were much closer to normal than the rest of the summer, and he hoped strong travel would continue through the shoulder season for people looking for long weekend getaways.

"The summer went OK. We certainly didn't perform to budget or to historical numbers, but we did a lot better than the general hospitality industry so we can't really complain right now," Ent said. "But it's still nowhere near what we've historically done."

Saturday was the third-busiest day of the year for cars passing through the toll onto Pensacola Beach, said Escambia County Commissioner Robert Bender.

A total of 21,759 cars passed through the toll Saturday, with a weekend total of 76,169 cars from Friday through Monday. That's higher than the previous three Labor Day weekends, which saw 70,224 vehicles, 62,837 cars and 65,882 vehicles, respectively.

July unemployment:Florida's unemployment rate up to 11.3% in July; jobless ranks grow by 122K people

Opting in:Florida opts to give unemployed an extra $300 a week through federal program

"I don't know if vehicles actually equate to tourism," Bender said, adding that tourist development tax dollar figures won't come in for August until late in September. "But I think what's been holding true for the last few months is that people can spread out on the beach."

Ent said Innisfree Hotels hasn't yet done much forecasting into what next year's booking may be like because October is its budget season, which is when that's determined. But he said no matter what, forecasting what occupancy and room rates will be like into next year will be difficult because no one has a handle on when things like corporate or group travel will return.

Bender said he believes the county will be able to extend the beach season by a few weeks this year to better support businesses. Visit Pensacola will continue marketing efforts in drive-able markets during the shoulder season to help bolster travel in the off months after Labor Day.

"We are slowly returning. We are seeing travel sentiment return. We're seeing that our drive markets are speaking to us," said Stacey with Visit Pensacola. "This is traditionally that last weekend of summer, if you will. So that being said, I think that our locals and our vacationers were coming out to just enjoy the beach."

The July bed tax collections, which were received in August, were down about 11% from the previous year and totaled about $1.8 million. That is better than June numbers, which were at $1.588 million.

So far, the county is about at $8.8 million in collections for the year, Bender said. Last fiscal year, the county collected a total of $12.3 million.

That makes it difficult for vacation marketing efforts for the area because bed tax dollars fund Visit Pensacola. This year's Visit Pensacola budget, which is unified with Pensacola Sports and ACE Pensacola, was reduced by $2.375 million or 25.7%.

Next year, the group is expecting its budget to be down another $1.37 million or 20% from where it ended this year.

"I think there's still that hesitation to travel or people will still take precautions regarding COVID, and as long as that is out there, that will still play a factor in any of our numbers," Bender said. "I think it's important for us to put our best foot forward and again, we have the beach that people can utilize and spread out and not feel on top of each other."

search_result.title: Summer not your favorite time of year? You're not alone | CNN
search_result.text:
CNN —

Yes, the summer begins now. It’s not me saying so. It’s the American people. Survey after survey has found that more Americans believe Memorial Day marks the unofficial start of summer than any other occasion (e.g., the beginning of baseball season or when pools open).

So as the calendar turns from the rebirth of spring to the sweltering heat of summer in this part of the world, here are five statistics to mark the occasion:

1. Summer is not most people’s favorite time of the year.

This one surprised me a little bit. Most people prefer warmer to cooler weather, and I always remembered summer being free time. Yet just 29% of Americans said summer was their favorite season in a 2020 CBS News poll. Fall (27%) and spring (25%) were right within the margin of error. A previous CBS News poll from 2013 had spring and summer tied at 33% for favorite season.

Polling often doesn’t show any of the meteorological summer months (June, July or August) to be the favorite of Americans. Frequently, it’s May, October or December.

Of course, there are regional variations. Americans in the northern part of the country are far more likely to list summer as their favorite season than those in the South. Southerners are more likely to list spring.

I guess New Englanders don’t like the backdoor cold fronts of the spring, while Southerners dislike the sweltering heat of summer.

2. Seventy-two degrees is usually just right.

Video Ad Feedback What NOT to do in a heat wave 01:14 - Source: CNN

One way to deal with the summer heat is to put on the air conditioning. Around 90% of Americans reportedly have AC, which is more than any country except Japan. About 70% have central AC.

A National Opinion Research Center poll last year asked those who had central AC what temperatures they set their thermostats to during the day and at night. During the day, the most popular answer was 72 degrees. During the night, the most popular answer was 72 degrees.

There’s a wide range in the data, with some people going as low as 55 degrees and some going as high as 76 degrees. Indeed, 13% of all of those with central AC said they slept in a temperature of 67 degrees or less during the summer. About 40% to 45% of people indicated that they kept their thermostats above 72 degrees during the day and at night.

What most Americans do agree upon is that having air conditioning is preferable to not having it. A 2019 CBS News poll inquired about whether Americans preferred having the windows open or the windows closed with the AC during a hot summer day. The clear winner was windows closed with the AC on at 65%, compared with 30% who said windows open.

3. Not going on vacation this weekend? Same here.

This Memorial Day weekend about 40 million Americans are expected to travel on a vacation, according to AAA. Most of those people (about 35 million) expect to travel by car. That means that most Americans aren’t taking a trip this weekend.

Most Americans do seem to want to take some vacation this summer, however. A Washington Post-Schar School poll conducted in April and May found that 72% of Americans plan to take a vacation away from their home this summer, although only 40% say they will definitely take one.

The biggest divides in whether someone goes on vacation are, perhaps not surprisingly, age and income. Those under 35 (82%) say they’re far more likely to say they plan on taking a vacation away from home than those who are 65 and older (60%). Those making $100,000 or more are more likely to say they’ll travel (87%) than those making less than $50,000 a year (59%).

Travelers tunnel through some breathtaking scenery near Bryce Canyon National Park in Utah. Andriy Blokhin/Adobe Stock

If people don’t end up traveling for vacation, it will be because of prices. Gas, flight and hotel and lodging prices were listed as much more important factors in making summer vacation plans than figuring out time off or fear over the coronavirus.

4. Most people just want to take a load off during summer.

If summer is known for taking vacations, then what do we actually want to do on those vacations? Well, it seems that most of us just want to be lazy.

That same Washington Post poll found that 76% of Americans said relaxing was a thing they liked to do on vacation. Next up (and within the margin of error of that result) was eating at restaurants (75%). Going to the beach or pool was in third place at 65%.

No other option hit a majority.

A day at the pool is always a summer option, even for those who don't want to exert too much energy. David Paul Morris/Bloomberg/Getty Images

Indeed, it seems Americans don’t want to exert too much energy in the summer months. Other polling indicates that Americans are far less likely to want to do athletic activities such as playing sports or going running than simply enjoying a meal during this summer vacation.

5. Summer vacation ends at a lot of different points.

Just as quickly as summer has begun, I hate to tell you that it will end just as quickly. When I was a kid, Labor Day marked that point. That’s when school, much to my undying hatred, began anew. Polling shows that more people think Labor Day marks the end of summer than the fall equinox.

What’s interesting is that this is sort of a Northern- and Middle Atlantic-centric point of view. A 2019 study by the Pew Research Center found that only 23% of American students go back to school after Labor Day. In New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania, over 80% of the studied school districts went back to school after Labor Day.

That year, 2% of students nationwide went back to school by August 2. Nearly half (43%) were back in school by the middle of August. This included the majority of students in the interior South (i.e., Alabama, Arkansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Tennessee and Texas).

This might explain why I always felt that back-to-school ads were airing too early in the summer. It turns out that for many kids, summer simply ended earlier.

Of course, we probably don’t need those ads airing in late May, as has happened in past years. We should give the kids a break.

search_result.title: So long summer, hello pumpkin spice season
search_result.text:
Rebecca Hanlon

YorkDailyRecord

The bright orange pumpkin pie frappe slowly got sucked up the straw as Hannah Stevens licked the cinnamon kissed whipped cream from her lips.

"I had to come get one as soon as I saw they posted it on Facebook," the 17-year-old Glen Rock girl said as she devoured breakfast one Saturday morning at the Rail Trail Café. "I love just about everything they make here — but I love pumpkin-flavored stuff even more."

Don't fear artificial flavors here. The Rail Trail Café boasts real pumpkin in its favorite fall beverage, jumping on the early arrival of autumn cravings as the Labor Day weekend marks the unofficial end of summer. York Countians might not be wearing sweaters and wool socks yet, but many residents are dreaming of chilly nights and cozy, comforting snacks.

If you're feeling the pumpkin fever creeping up already, try these treats that will have you dreaming of jack-o-lanterns and hay rides.

Sweet and Spicy Pumpkin Seeds

Pumpkin seeds are a great snack if you're looking to fill up on some healthy nutrients without breaking your calorie bank. These simple recipes, both spicy and sweet, help add some excitement to plain pumpkin seeds.

Pepita is a Spanish culinary term for the pumpkin seed, the edible seed of a pumpkin or other cultivar of squash. One-quarter cup of pumpkin seeds contains nearly half of the recommended daily amount of magnesium and are a rich source of zinc as well as plant-based omega-3s.

One cup has just 285 calories, so a small handful will go a long way.

Recipe for sweet pumpkin seeds

INGREDIENTS:

• 1/4 cup of plain pumpkin seeds

• 1 teaspoon sugar

• 1 teaspoon cinnamon

INSTRUCTIONS:

Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Spray the pumpkin seeds with cooking oil before tossing them in the sugar and cinnamon. Spread the seeds out on a baking sheet and roast for 15 to 20 minutes, tossing halfway through.

Recipe for spicy pumpkin seeds

INGREDIENTS:

• 1/4 cup of plain pumpkin seeds

• 1/2 teaspoon garlic powder

• 1/2 teaspoon cayenne

• 1/2 teaspoon coriander

INSTRUCTIONS:

Again, spray the pumpkin seeds with cooking oil. Toss with the garlic powder, cayenne and coriander. Roast at 400 degrees for 15 to 20 minutes, tossing halfway through.

More pumpkin spice goodness

Spiced pumpkin cookies

INGREDIENTS:

2/3cup whole-wheat pastry flour

2/3cup all-purpose flour

1teaspoon baking powder

1/2teaspoon baking soda

1/2teaspoon salt

1teaspoon ground cinnamon

1/2teaspoon ground ginger

1/4teaspoon ground allspice

1/4teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg

2large eggs

3/4cup packed light brown sugar (or 1/3 cup Splenda Sugar Blend for Baking)

3/4cup canned unseasoned pumpkin puree

1/4cup canola oil

1/4cup dark molasses 1cup raisins

INSTRUCTIONS

Preheat oven to 350 degrees.

Coat three baking sheets with cooking spray.

Whisk whole-wheat flour, all-purpose flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, ginger, allspice and nutmeg in a large bowl.

Whisk eggs, brown sugar (or Splenda), pumpkin, oil and molasses in a second bowl until well combined.

Stir the wet ingredients and raisins into the dry ingredients until thoroughly combined.

Drop the batter by level tablespoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheets, spacing the cookies 1 1/2 inches apart.

Bake the cookies until firm to the touch and lightly golden on top, 10 to 12 minutes. Transfer to a wire rack to cool.

NUTRITIONAL INFORMATION

Nutritional information per serving (the recipe makes three dozen cookies): calories, 72; fat, 2g; cholesterol, 10 mg; carbohydrates, 13g; sugar, 7g; protein, 1g; fiber, 1g; sodium, 70 mg; potassium, 87g.

Source: "Eating Well," www.eatingwell.com

Pumpkin coconut soup

INGREDIENTS:

• 1 1/2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil

• 1 cup chopped onion

• 3 garlic cloves, minced

• 3 cups solid-pack pumpkin, canned

• 2 cups chicken or vegetable broth

• 1 teaspoons sugar

• 1/2 teaspoon ground allspice

• 1/2 teaspoon dried crushed red pepper

• 1 1/2 cups unsweetened coconut milk, divided

• Salt and pepper

• Pepitas (pumpkin seeds) for garnish

INSTRUCTIONS:

Heat the oil in a heavy large pot over medium heat. Add the onion and garlic. Sauté until golden, about 10 minutes.

Add the pumpkin, broth, sugar, allspice and crushed red pepper. Bring to a boil. Reduce the heat. Cover and simmer until flavors blend, about 30 minutes.

Working in batches, puree the soup in a blender until smooth. Return the soup to the pot. Bring the soup to a simmer, thinning with coconut milk to the desired consistency. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

A one cup serving is about 200 calories.

Ladle the soup into bowls. Sprinkle with the pepitas, drizzle with a teaspoon of coconut milk and serve.

Homemade pumpkin pie coffee creamer

INGREDIENTS:

• 16 fl. oz. of heavy whipping cream

• 4 teaspoons maple syrup

• ¼ cup pure pumpkin puree

• ½ teaspoon pumpkin pie spice

INSTRUCTIONS:

Pour the heavy whipping cream, maple syrup, pumpkin puree and pumpkin pie spice into a blender. Pulse until well blended. Pour into a pitcher or air right container and store in the refrigerator for a week. Use as a sweetener and creamer in fresh coffee.

search_result.title: Jazz Funeral mourners say 'goodbye' to Summer 2016
search_result.text:
Gray Hughes

rghughes@dmg.gannett.com

As the sound of jazz music and mourning takes over the Bethany Beach Boardwalk the evening of Sept. 5, a casket is carried down the boardwalk.

But the people on the boardwalk aren't mourning the loss of an individual.

Though it officially ends with the fall equinox on Sept. 22 this year, Labor Day marks the unofficial end of life of the summer season at the Delaware beaches.

So a group of mourners at the Bethany Beach Boardwalk laid to rest the Summer 2016 like they've done for more than three decades — in the style of a New Orleans funeral.

"Being able to shed a few tears for 'Dearly Departed Summer' is the only requirement for those who join the procession," said Carolyn Bacon, one of the assistant chairpersons for this year's Jazz Funeral, in a press release. "Visitors and locals of all ages are invited to join in the procession and have as much fun as they want at the Jazz Funeral. We invite those who attend to dress up in their favorite costumes and have a great time."

Now in its 31st year, the Jazz Funeral not only encompasses the solemn procession down the Bethany Beach Boardwalk, but also three jazz bands who lead the procession as well as a silent auction the Friday beforehand to help benefit the Sussex County Habitat for Humanity, American Red Cross, Sussex County Big Brothers Big Sisters organization, the American Cancer Society and the Delaware Audubon Society and Chesapeake Audubon Society.

Participants in the Jazz Funeral wear black shrouds, dark sunglasses or costumes.

Some carry flowers or reeds and others carry large umbrellas to really call to mind a true New Orleans funeral.

Three bands lead the way for the crowd of mourners: the Dixie Cats, the Downtown Dixieland Band and the Jazz Funeral Irregulars. Carried along with the procession is a casket with a mannequin representing the summer of 2016, who is taken to its final resting stop at the Boardwalk Bandstand.

Hermine didn't scare people away from Bethany Beach

Despite the threat of bad weather earlier in the weekend, the boardwalk was flooded with people to celebrate the unofficial end of summer.

"I think summer is a special time," said Susan Aghazarian, of Phoenix, Maryland who was taking in the parade for the first time. "This is is a great way to say thank you to the hard working lifeguards who keep us safe all summer. I think it's a neat way to show our appreciation."

During the procession, the bands play somber, funeral music. But once they reach the Boardwalk Bandstand, they go uptempo to really celebrate the end of summer.

"This is a way to say goodbye to a friend who has been with you all summer," said Peggy Saur, of Bethany Beach. "This is my first time to watch it. I've never seen anything like it."

Busy Independence Day weekend in Bethany Beach kicks off

This year's Jazz Funeral was never in doubt despite the possibility of bad weather from Tropical Storm Hermine. The Jazz Funeral sent out an email over the weekend saying the show would go on rain or shine.

"Our HOA was warning us about big waves that were supposed to hit Bethany over the weekend," said Donna Panzarella, of Washington, DC. "But we decided to come out. It turned out nice."

Panzarella, who was at the Jazz Funeral along with her husband, wasn't the only person concerned about the weather this weekend.

"The weather did impact my arrival," said Greg Kametz, of Baltimore. "We rented a place for two weeks and we were supposed to come Saturday but we came Sunday instead. The whole Jazz Funeral is a nice tradition."

search_result.title: Rocky Mountain National Park fall planner: Timed-entry permits ...
search_result.text:
Labor Day weekend marks the unofficial end of the popular summer outdoor recreation season for many places.

That's not the case at Rocky Mountain National Park. Visitors continue to pour into the park in September and October to take in the fall colors and experience the sights and sounds of elk.

The color of aspen and bugling of elk make autumn among the best times to visit, as evidenced by September being the park's third-busiest month and October close behind.

But before you go, it's even more important to plan ahead before visiting the third-busiest national park this year so you can navigate the required timed-entry permit reservations, mask requirements, closures due to fires and ever-changing road conditions.

Timed-entry permits at Rocky Mountain National Park

This requirement to access the park has caught many visitors off guard.

The park has for the second summer implemented a timed-entry permit reservation system that went into effect May 28 and runs through Oct. 11.

The permits allow for two-hour entry windows into the Bear Lake area starting at the 5-7 a.m. slot and ending at the 4-6 p.m. slot. Permits to enter the rest of the park also offer two-hour windows, but start with a 9-11 a.m. slot and end with 1-3 p.m. entry.

You can access the park without a timed-entry permit before 5 a.m. and after 6 p.m. for the Bear Lake corridor and before 9 a.m. and after 3 p.m. for the rest of the park, excluding the Bear Lake Road corridor.

Starting at 10 a.m. MT Sept. 1, you can make reservations for times and dates that remain open for that month and for all of October. Not all times and dates will be open in September because those slots became available starting Aug. 1

There is a limited number of permits that will be made available for purchase at 5 p.m. the day prior to your visit. These permits sell out quickly.

All timed-entry permits must be obtained by visiting www.recreation.gov.

Mask requirement in effect for Rocky Mountain National Park

Make sure to pack your masks this year.

As of Aug. 16, the National Park Service announced masks must be worn by visitors, employees and contractors inside all park service buildings, while using public transportation systems and in crowded outdoor spaces where physical distancing cannot be maintained regardless of vaccination status or community transmission levels.

The park service said the new requirement follows the latest science and guidance from the CDC. The announcement came amid rising concern over the spread of the delta variant of the coronavirus.

Be aware that congested areas where you may be required to wear a mask outdoors include Moraine Park Road and Horseshoe Park, which attract large crowds to see elk. Other areas include the park's shuttle service stations, popular overlooks along Trail Ridge Road and some parking lots and trails, especially in the Bear Lake corridor.

Cameron Peak Fire: COVID-19 had firefighter fighting for his life

Road conditions in Rocky Mountain National Park

Yes, Trail Ridge Road was temporarily closed due to snow and icy conditions at higher elevations Aug. 20, but it was back open later that day.

Normally the highest paved road in the U.S. doesn't close for winter until the third week of October and can remain open longer depending on conditions. But Colorado is known for its autumn snows, so keep a close eye on conditions.

The gravel Fall River Road is usually closed for winter the first week of October.

For up-to-date road conditions in the park, call 970-586-1222, or follow the park's Twitter site @RockyNPS or Facebook page at www.facebook.com/RockyNPS.

Cameron Peak Fire, East Troublesome Fire impacts

Last year's Cameron Peak and East Troublesome wildfires, which are the two largest wildfires in state history, converged on the park.

Despite that, the two fires only burned about 10% of the park.

The west side of the park took the brunt of the burn.

Park visitors entering from the Grand Lake Entrance should not stop or park along the roadside from the entrance to the Onahu Trail due to hazard trees along the road from the East Troublesome Fire. There is no access to trails, picnic areas or parking areas along this section of the road, including the Harbison Picnic Area and the Green Mountain Trail.

Most of the Sun Valley Trail remains closed but all other trails on the west side have reopened.

On the east side, the Spruce Lake Trail, Poudre River Trail, Mirror Lake Trail and Comanche Peak Trail, as well as the Beaver Mountain area and trails remain closed

Moraine Park and Glacier Basin campgrounds are open but sites are secured through reservations only. Those reservations are booked well in advance.

Moraine Park Campground sites are available on a first-come, first-served basis after Oct. 11. The Glacier Basin Campground closes Sept. 13.

For up-to-date information, visit www.nps.gov/romo.

A look back: How Estes Park, Rocky Mountain National Park escaped major fire damage

What to know about elk viewing

The elk bugling season starts in late August and generally runs through mid-October.

The best places to view elk are in the Moraine Park and Horseshoe Park areas on the east side and Kawuneeche Valley on the west side.

Rangers and volunteers will be on hand to assist visitors in these areas during busy times.

You are likely to see elk right in Estes Park.

Dawn and dusk are when elk are most active.

During elk rut season, foot and horse traffic in the following areas of the park will be limited to established roadways and designated trails from 5 p.m. to 10 a.m.:

Horseshoe Park

Upper Beaver Meadows

Moraine Park

Harbison Meadow

Holzwarth Meadow

The closures run from Sept. 1 through Oct. 31, according to a park news release.

Some fishing areas are also affected by closures during elk rut season — posted areas in the Fall, Thompson and Colorado rivers will be closed to fishing from 5 p.m. to 7 a.m.

"The purpose of the closures is to prevent disturbance and harassment of elk during their fall mating period and to enhance elk visitor viewing opportunities," the park said in its release. "As always, elk calling and the use of spotlights or vehicle headlights for spotting wildlife is prohibited in Rocky Mountain National Park."

What to know about aspen viewing

Generally, aspen start to change colors in early September in the 9,000- to 11,000-foot range, progressively working lower in elevation by mid-September.

Color can last into October but weather can dictate how long and how spectacular the fall display will be.

On the east side, check out Hidden Valley, Bear Lake Road, Longs Peak and Wild Basin. On the west side, visit Kawuneeche Valley and the Fairview Overlook.

search_result.title: NJ problems pile up during recess
search_result.text:
MICHAEL CATALINI

Associated Press

TRENTON With the full Legislature not meeting again until after this November’s election and Gov. Chris Christie often out of state in his White House bid, New Jersey’s problems are piling up.

The Labor Day weekend might mark the unofficial end of summer for many, but New Jersey’s Legislature has slowed its typically brisk pace ahead of Election Day, which will feature the Assembly at the top of the ballot for the first time since 1999.

The break is not out of the ordinary in New Jersey, where legislators typically take this time off. But this year the state is facing serious issues, including a fiscal crunch gripping Atlantic City; the state’s transportation trust fund lurching toward insolvency; and the nearly $80 billion public pension teetering toward unsustainability. The break also coincides with Christie’s frequent out-of-state travels as he seeks the Republican nomination for president.

Aside from tradition, another reason for the break is the coming election, which could have record low turnout, according to Rider University political science adjunct professor Ben Dworkin.

“Every time you take a vote in Trenton, somebody might be upset,” he said. “None of these legislators want to do that on the eve of an election.”

Some of the big issues prove thornier than others. For instance, the Legislature has already sent Christie a five-bill package addressing Atlantic City’s struggling economy. The legislation includes a payment-in-lieu-of-taxes plan that aims to stabilize tax revenue in the resort town. The bill is awaiting action from Christie, who does not typically discuss pending legislation.

But other issues, like transportation funding, could require an unpopular hike in the state’s 10.5-cent-per-gallon gas tax, which has not changed since 1989. At issue is the roughly $1.2 billion transportation trust fund, which was created to pay for road and bridge work, but currently pays for debt. New projects are funded by additional bonding coupled with a loan from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

It’s one of the top issues for both business and environmental groups, two groups who are not typically in agreement.

Stakeholders say it’s urgent for the Legislature and Christie to address the issue, but they stop short of expressing any frustration over the lawmakers’ absence.

“All of us probably would like things to move forward faster,” said New Jersey Chamber of Commerce President Tom Bracken at a news conference announcing a business summit later this month in Atlantic City. “But you know historically they take this time off. With the election coming up I think they realize if they were here not much would get done, so be it.”

The pension fund is also contentious and prospects for an agreement between Christie — who invites unions and Democrats to re-negotiate a solution — and the Legislature seem bleak. Democrats question Christie’s trustworthiness. The bad blood goes back to the disintegration of a 2011 deal in which union members conceded certain cost-of-living adjustments in exchange for the Christie administration paying more into the pension fund, but lower-than-expected revenues in 2014 resulted in Christie reducing the payment. Unions sued, and eventually the state Supreme Court refused to require Christie to make the payment.

Unions don’t fault the Democrat-led Legislature for taking off, but blame Christie vetoing legislation that would have made higher payments to the pension.

“The Legislature is doing its job in New Jersey,” New Jersey Education Association President Wendell Steinhauer said. “Our problem is a governor who vetoes the common-sense bills they pass and who has abandoned this state at such a critical time.”

A message to Christie’s office seeking comment was not returned.

The Legislature won’t be totally off. The state Senate has met roughly once a month since July, with the next voting session scheduled for Sept. 24. Legislators have also sent Christie several dozen bills before the summer break began, many of which are still on his desk.

search_result.title: Rose everyday: If summer never ends, nor should the rose and ...
search_result.text:
Gina Birch

Special to The News-Press

Labor Day Weekend marks the unofficial end of summer, even though you wouldn’t know it by local thermometers, which remain deep in the red. The forthcoming holiday, a three-day affair for many, is the last hoorah before the days start getting shorter and the nights begin to cool — if only by a few degrees.

The holiday weekend has a long tradition of backyard barbecues, beach time and boating, all of which beg for cool refreshing beverages.

August is National Rose Month, and even though that celebration wraps up today, rose is still hot, and oh-so-cool, to have on hand for your Labor Day celebration. It comes in boxes, bottles and cans, with bubbles and without.

The pink drink ranges from sweet to bone dry and comes in prices that vary widely, from less than $10 to more than $100. Enjoyed solo, with food or in cocktails, rose is one of the most versatile wines.

More:Late summer rum guide: How to choose and sip rum, plus classic recipes

And:Can it: Six new canned cocktails to quench the dog days of summer

Every summer, I find myself with more bottles of rose than I can possibly drink, so I host a Rose All Day Brunch, pop as many corks, tops and screw caps as possible, and see what stands out.

This year, in the canned category, Jetway is a newly launched wine seltzer. The creators wanted a more natural seltzer product, so they tapped into the power of the grape as a sweetener rather than a bunch of additives. Jetway's rose seltzer comes infused with peach, Fijian ginger, yerba mate and orange peel. Warning: This refreshing beverage goes down fast and easy, and it's $20 for a four-pack.

For a classic, Provencal-style rose, Rose Gold ($19.99) gets a gold star. It’s dry, pale pink and slightly floral with fresh red fruit and a hint of spice. A blend of cinsault and grenache, Rose Gold is not a passive wine. It went remarkably well with quiche and salad.

Alma Rosa's Vin Gris of Pinot Noir ($35) proved to be another brunch favorite. Perhaps it was the touch of salinity that literally made your mouth water and kept you going back for more. A rose full of tropical fruit flavors, this is perfect for a Sunday funday — or any day for that matter.

Also:Sip it up a notch: Master food and wine pairings with these summery recipes

Ram’s Gate Rose ($38) hails from Sonoma, California and is mostly pinot noir with 25% grenache. This wine is as elegant as the bottle in which it's packaged. The salmon color photographed well with a salmon appetizer, and the flavors blended nicely, too. Ram’s Gate Rose has some strawberry and melon notes, and it proved to be another brunch fave.

On the sweeter side of life, you'll find Lillet Rose ($20). This iconic French aperitif makes a great addition to Champagne for a sparkling cocktail. Lillet (pronounced lee-LAY) is a wine that is fortified with citrus liqueurs. It’s been made in Bordeaux since 1872 and although sweet, it is not cloying. The rose has flavors of orange that make for a fantastic spritzer, with seasonal fruit for appearance and taste.

Traditionally, Lillet is mixed with spirits such as vodka and gin.

I got this recipe a couple of years ago from the Lobby Bar at The New York Edition, a hotel in Manhattan. Although it might be a little fancy for a Labor Day cookout, it would work when the party moves indoors, and it would be perfect for a holiday weekend brunch.

Recipe: A Martini by Any Other Name

Ingredients

2 ounces Hendrick’s Gin

¾ ounce Lillet Rose

¼ ounce Italicus

2 dashes Peychaud’s bitters

3 muddled rose petals

Directions

Combine all ingredients in a shaker. Add ice, stir and then strain into a coup glass. For an extra touch, garnish with a rose petal.

While we’re at it, how about this recipe for a less-fussy cocktail that will still have your friends talking. It has a dash of nostalgia, is easy to execute, and it tastes good to boot.

Recipe: Nolet's Silver Firecracker Gin + Tonic

Ingredients

1½ ounces NOLET’S Silver Gin

1 Bomb Pop (or other ice pop)

Frozen raspberries, blueberries

4 ounces tonic water

Directions

Fill a balloon glass with ice and frozen fruit. Add Nolet's Silver, tonic water and ice pop. Enjoy.

Cheers to your Labor Day celebrations and bidding a fond farewell to summer! Now, if only those temperatures would cool just a bit.

Gina Birch writes about food, wine and spirits for The News-Press and at thebirchbeat.blogspot.com. Follow her as @ginabirch on Twitter and find her on Facebook.

Editors

USA TODAY

A Labor Day weekend like no other

The first Monday of September marks Labor Day, signaling the unofficial end of summer, the start of school and a change in the way we act and dress for the rest of the year. Labor Day also has historical significance: It has been a federal holiday since 1894 aimed at celebrating the contributions of American workers. For many, that usually means a long holiday weekend full of traveling, camping trips, and backyard barbecues. And while all of those activities are still possible in 2020, they'll likely look a lot different this year amid the coronavirus pandemic. Health officials, including Dr. Anthony Fauci, have cautioned against gatherings this Labor Day weekend, as more outbreaks are traced to small gatherings of family and friends.

Prefer to listen? Check out the 5 things podcast below and subscribe for free on Apple Podcasts:

Serena Williams seeks to continue US Open run

The quest for the all-time Grand Slam record continues for Serena Williams, who will take the U.S. Open court Monday in the first match on Arthur Ashe Stadium. Williams, the No. 3 seed, will face No. 15 seed Maria Sakkari of Greece in the Round of 16. Williams has won 23 Grand Slam singles titles, one short of the all-time record set by Margaret Smith Court. Of those 23, six have come at the U.S. Open — which ties fellow American Chris Evert for most all time — but Williams hasn't celebrated a singles title at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center since 2014.

WikiLeaks' Julian Assange fights extradition to U.S. to face spying charges

The extradition hearing of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange resumes in London on Monday after being postponed due to the coronavirus. Washington wants British authorities to extradite Assange to the U.S. to face charges of conspiracy to commit computer intrusion. The Department of Justice has indicted him on 18 counts, alleging 17 forms of espionage and 1 instance of computer misuse crimes connected to WikiLeaks' dissemination of secret U.S. military documents provided to him by former U.S. Army intelligence analyst Chelsea Manning. Assange, 49, denies the charges and claims the U.S. documents WikiLeaks published in 2010 exposed war crimes and human rights abuses by the U.S. military in Iraq. WikiLeaks says the U.S. is trying to criminalize journalistic activity and if Assange is extradited it could have serious implications for First Amendment protections.

Extreme heat is a concern for firefighters

A heat wave is expected to spread triple-digit temperatures over much of California through Monday as a high-pressure system perches over the Western United States. Officials urged people to conserve electricity to ease strain on the state’s power grid and to follow social distancing and mask requirements when they hit recreational areas. A record-breaking 117 degrees was recorded in Los Angeles’ San Fernando Valley on Saturday and temperatures in the Central Valley are expected to be in the triple digits until Thursday. The extreme heat is a cause for concern for firefighters battling wildfires across the state, including the Creek Fire in eastern Fresno County and the SQF Complex fire in Tulare County.

More than 200 campers rescued by helicopter as Creek Fire prompts state of emergency in California: What we know

Should Americans be concerned about election meddling this November? New book explores past elections

A new book that claims to be the first in-depth analysis of election interference "from the dawn of the modern era to the 2016 Russian intervention in the U.S. election" comes out Monday. "Meddling in the Ballot Box: The Causes and Effects of Partisan Electoral Interventions," by Dov H. Levin, a political scientist at the University of Hong Kong, says he has found that meddling could "potentially determine the election result in 2020, as it is very likely to have done many times in the past both in the U.S. and elsewhere." As Americans reflect on the threat of Russia wading into November's presidential election, the book delivers the score on topics such as election interference, common tactics used by meddlers, which country has meddled the most, and which country is the top target. But you'll have to pick up the book to find those answers.

ROB MAADDI

AP

Patrick Mahomes and the Super Bowl champion Kansas City Chiefs will kick off the NFL season against the upstart Detroit Lions in a matchup of high-powered offenses and will host Jalen Hurts and the Philadelphia Eagles in a Super Bowl rematch on “Monday Night Football” in Week 11.

Aaron Rodgers will make his New York Jets debut in the first Monday night game of the season against the Buffalo Bills and later faces the Miami Dolphins in the NFL's first Black Friday game on Nov. 24.

Thanks to Rodgers' arrival in the Big Apple, the Jets will have six nationally televised games, including their first Sunday night game since 2011 when they take on the Chiefs on Oct. 1. That'll be the first ever Mahomes-Rodgers matchup.

“It’s not going to be monotonous with all the 1 o’clock games we’re used to,” Jets coach Robert Saleh said on NFL Network.

Coming off their second championship in four seasons, the Chiefs will host the Lions on Sept. 7 on “Thursday Night Football.” The Lions finished 9-8 last season after a 1-6 start and knocked Rodgers and the Green Bay Packers out of the playoffs with a 20-16 victory at Lambeau Field in the final regular-season game.

Mahomes, the two-time NFL MVP, led the Chiefs to a 38-35 comeback win over the Eagles in the Super Bowl. The teams will battle at Arrowhead Stadium on Nov. 20.

Fans will get their first look at Rodgers in his new green-and-white No. 8 Jets jersey when New York hosts Josh Allen and the Bills in an AFC East matchup on Sept. 11.

The NFL released the full schedule for its 104th season on Thursday night after revealing five international games and several others earlier in the day and Wednesday.

Other highlights include a rematch of the NFC championship game in Week 13 and a rematch of the AFC title game in Week 17. Hurts and the Eagles will host the San Francisco 49ers on Dec. 3. The Chiefs will host Joe Burrow and the Cincinnati Bengals on New Year's Eve.

The New England Patriots also announced seven-time Super Bowl champion Tom Brady will be honored at the team's home opener against the Eagles on Sept. 10. Brady, who led the Patriots to six Super Bowl titles, retired in February after spending the last three seasons with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

On Wednesday, the NFL announced that Trevor Lawrence and the Jacksonville Jaguars will become the first NFL team to play two international games in the same season when they spend back-to-back weeks in London.

The Jaguars will host the Atlanta Falcons at Wembley Stadium on Oct. 1 and visit the Bills at Tottenham Hotspur Stadium on Oct. 8. The Jaguars were set to play two designated home games in London in 2020 but the pandemic canceled those plans.

The Tennessee Titans will host the Baltimore Ravens at Tottenham Hotspur Stadium on Oct. 15. The Chiefs will host the Dolphins in Germany at Eintracht Frankfurt Stadium on Nov. 5. The Patriots will host the Indianapolis Colts on Nov. 12, also in Frankfurt.

INDIANAPOLIS – Helio Castroneves’ pursuit of a historic fourth Indianapolis 500 victory will still be alive in 2020. After leaving full-time IndyCar series competition with the end of the 2017 campaign, the 44-year-old Brazilian star driver will again race for Team Penske during the month of May in a part-time effort, according to team spokesperson Sarah Bonkowski.

Team Penske director of communications Merrill Cain also confirmed a report that Castroneves will race for the team in the newly-named GMR Grand Prix on May 9, also at Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

"That is the plan," Cain said.

Last May, when Castroneves finished 18th in the Greatest Spectacle in Racing – just his fourth finish outside the top 15 in 19 appearances – team owner Roger Penske hinted one of the race’s most successful drivers would be back for its 104th running on May 24, but nothing was set in stone.

Penske told The Associated Press before last year’s race that his commitment to Castroneves hanging onto a sliver of his illustrious open-wheel racing career was set to last three years after starting in 2018. After his 2017 IndyCar season where he won once (Iowa), grabbed three poles and fourth in the series, Castroneves left the series full-time to join Penske’s sports car program. That season was also the last that Team Penske ran four full-time entries.

In the WeatherTech SportsCar Championship, Castroneves has finished in seventh and fourth place, respectively, in the series championship the past two years. with seven podium finishes and a 2018 win at Mid-Ohio.

In his 11th attempt to join A.J. Foyt, Al Unser and Rick Mears as the only four-time Indy 500 winners, Castroneves is coming off two of his three worst finishes at the race, including 18th-place a year ago while a lap down and 27th in 2018 after a crash on Lap 146 while he was driving fifth. The legend has finished second-place three times during his Indy 500 career, including as recently as 2017, during his last full-season stint in the series.

A year ago, Castroneves struggled and finished 21st in the IndyCar Grand Prix after landing top-six in each of the race's first five runnings.

Team Penske has won each of the past two Indy 500s, with Will Power and Simon Pagenaud sweeping both races held during May at IMS.

search_result.title: Cubs: Quick fix not part of plan
search_result.text:
By John Perrotto, Special for USA TODAY

The Cubs went 61-101 in 2012, which gave them the second-worst record in the major leagues

Last season also marked the 104th anniversary of the Cubs' last World Series title

The Cubs don't seem close to removing their Billy Goat Curse

Theo Epstein knew trying to reverse a curse with the Chicago Cubs likely would take a lot longer than it did with the Boston Red Sox.

After one year as Cubs president of baseball operations, the former Red Sox general manager has been proved correct.

The Cubs went 61-101 in 2012, which gave them the second-worst record in the major leagues, behind the Houston Astros, who finished 55-107. It marked the Cubs' first 100-loss season since 1966, and Chicago finished two losses from the franchise record of 103 set in 1962 and matched in 1966.

Last season also marked the 104th anniversary of the Cubs' last World Series title.

Epstein took over his hometown Red Sox in 2003, and they won their first World Series title in 86 years the following season, eradicating the so-called Curse of the Bambino. But the Cubs don't seem close to removing their Billy Goat Curse.

"I'm not going to sit here and say, 'Don't worry about 101 losses because we have a magic plan to win a World Series in 2013, it's going to happen, so be there now,'" Epstein told news reporters in his season-ending news conference. "That's not the case. I think we're trying to communicate that there is a plan, there is a vision.

"It might be a little bit longer term than we all want it to be, but we're committed to it ... and that there's a great reward at the end. We can't guarantee results, but I can tell everybody that we're not going to be satisfied until we're in the postseason year-in and year-out and we're in contention every year."

Epstein has the people he wants in place to help carry out his vision in general manager Jed Hoyer, manager Dale Sveum and senior vice president of scouting and development Jason McLeod. All were part of the Red Sox's organization when they won in 2004.

But the difference between the Red Sox and Cubs is that Boston was in position to win when Epstein took over as GM in 2003. They got within one game of the World Series that season, losing to the New York Yankees in seven games in the American League Championship Series.

The Cubs, conversely, haven't been to the playoffs since 2008 and haven't won a postseason game since 2003.

Epstein and Hoyer know how far they have to go to be competitive but aren't looking for quick fixes. They didn't hang on to veterans this past season when they fell out of contention, instead trading right-hander Ryan Dempster, left-hander Paul Maholm, catcher Geovany Soto and utility players Jeff Baker and Reed Johnson for prospects.

The Cubs will listen to offers this offseason for left fielder Alfonso Soriano, who had a career-high 108 RBI in 2012 and hit 32 home runs. The Cubs are willing to eat a large chunk of the $36 million on the final two years of his eight-year, $136 million contract if they get a decent haul in return.

But the Cubs aren't completely writing off 2013. They know the addition of a second wild card in each league makes the road to the postseason a little easier.

Yet the Cubs are only looking to add veterans via trade if they have one year left on their contracts or sign free agents to one-year deals so they will be able to flip those players in July should they fall out of the race.

They have other reasons to look ahead to next season, most notably to see how much improvement first baseman Anthony Rizzo, catcher Welington Castillo and right-hander Jeff Samardzija make.

All three look like key parts of the future. Rizzo hit .285 with 15 home runs and 48 RBI in 87 games, Castillo batted .265 with five homers in 52 games and Samardzija went 9-13 with a 3.81 ERA in his first season as a starter.

***

Where the Cubs stand at each position

Catcher

Welington Castillo took the starting job late in the season as a rookie and looks like a potential keeper. He hit .265 with five home runs in 52 games, providing more pop than Steve Clevenger, a fellow rookie who batted .201 with one homer in 69 games. Clevenger is considered the better defensive catcher, but Castillo shows enough promise with the bat to be the No.1 backstop.

First base

Anthony Rizzo was a bright spot in a 101-loss season as he hit .285 with 15 home runs in 87 games after being recalled from Class AAA (Des Moines) Iowa. The 23-year-old left-handed hitter figures to be a fixture in the middle of the batting order for years. Bryan LaHair played well enough in the first half of his first full major league season to be selected to play in the All-Star Game. He hit .259 with 16 homers in 130 games.

Second base

Darwin Barney won his first Gold Glove Award in 2012 as he made two errors in 731 total chances. Barney hit .254 with seven home runs in 156 games and needs to improve his .299 on-base percentage if he is going to stay in the No.2 spot in the batting order. Adrian Cardenas once was considered an intriguing prospect, but he hit .183 in 45 games in his major league debut in 2012.

Shortstop

Starlin Castro, 22, has been selected to two All-Star Games, which is why the Cubs signed him to a seven-year, $60 million contract extension that takes effect in 2013. Castro loses his focus at times in the field, but he has a good blend of power and speed, hitting .283 with 14 home runs and 25 stolen bases this year. Castro blocks strong-armed prospect Junior Lake, who hit .279 with 10 homers in 103 games at Class AA.

Third base

Ian Stewart likely will get another crack at the starting job in spring training after having a miserable 2012 following his acquisition from the Colorado Rockies. Stewart is arbitration eligible, and the Cubs could non-tender him if they find a better alternative. He batted .201 with five home runs in 55 games before having season-ending wrist surgery. Utility infielder Luis Valbuena made the majority of starts at third but hit .219 with four homers in 90 games. Prospect Josh Vitters was overmatched in his first trip to the majors, hitting .121 with two homers in 36 games.

Left field

Alfonso Soriano had one of the best seasons of his 14-year career in 2012. He no longer is a stolen-base threat, and the Cubs would love to trade him for prospects. But Soriano has full no-trade rights as a player with a minimum of 10 years in the majors and five with the same club, and he also has $36 million left on the last two years of his eight-year, $136 million contract.

Center field

Brett Jackson is expected to start next season in the minors after hitting .175 with four home runs and striking out in 59 of 142 plate appearances in his first trip to the majors. If they can't find a stopgap for center, the Cubs will go with a platoon of speedy left-handed hitting Tony Campana, who has been successful on 54 of 59 stolen bases attempts in two major league seasons, and right-handed batting Dave Sappelt, who hit .275 with two homers in 26 late-season games.

Right field

David DeJesus had a decent 2012 after signing a two-year, $10 million contract as a free agent. He batted .263 with nine home runs out of the leadoff spot, but 61 walks helped boost his on-base percentage to .350.

Starters

Right-hander Matt Garza, who led Cubs starters with a 3.32 ERA in 2011, was limited to 18 starts in 2012 because of a stress reaction in his elbow and went 5-7 with a 3.91 ERA. Right-hander Jeff Samardzija was thrust into the ace role and acquitted himself well in his first full season as a starter by going 9-13 with a 3.81 ERA. Left-hander Travis Wood was 6-13 with a 4.27 ERA in 26 starts and is all but assured of a spot in the 2013 rotation. The Cubs need more depth.

Bullpen

James Russell figures to be the top left-hander after posting a 3.25 ERA in 77 games, with Jeff Beliveau possibly serving as a second lefty. The Cubs are excited to get a look at right-hander Arodys Vizcaino, acquired from the Atlanta Braves in a July trade for Paul Maholm. Hard-throwing Vizcaino was recovering from Tommy John elbow surgery at the time of the deal but should be in the mix with several other righties that include Michael Bowden, Zach Putnam, Jaye Chapman, Alberto Cabrera, Lendy Castillo, Rafael Dolis, Carlos Gutierrez and Tony Zych.

Closer

Carlos Marmol is the closer — for now. Despite the ups and downs he has suffered in his three full seasons as the closer, he has 92 saves in that span.

***

Prospects to watch

SS Javier Baez: The 19-year-old's time in the Arizona Fall League ended in strange fashion when he suffered a non-displaced break of his right thumb while high-fiving a teammate. Baez, the Cubs' first-round draft pick in 2011, made his professional debut this season and hit .333 with 12 home runs and 20 stolen bases in 57 games for low-Class A Peoria (Ill.) before being bumped to Daytona (Daytona Beach, Fla.), where he batted .244 with four homers in 23 games. Baez is a pure hitter with outstanding bat speed who should hit for power and average.

OF Jorge Soler: The Cubs signed the Cuban defector to a nine-year, $30 million major league contract as a free agent in June, and he hit a combined .299 with five home runs and 12 steals in 34 games with the rookie-level Arizona League Cubs and Peoria. Soler, 20, has big-time power potential and outstanding bat speed. Some scouts think he is one step below Oakland Athletics outfielder Yoenis Cespedes, another Cuban defector.

OF Albert Almora: Chicago's first-round selection in this year's draft had a solid pro debut, hitting .331 with two homers in 33 games with the Arizona League Cubs and short-season Boise. The 18-year-old is lauded as much for his leadership skills and work ethic as he is for his considerable athletic talent.

OF Brett Jackson: He has the potential to be a Gold Glove center fielder with power but has to cut down on strikeouts. Jackson, 24, whiffed 158 times in 407 at-bats with Class AAA (Des Moines) Iowa this year, then was punched out 59 more times in 120 at-bats after being called up by the Cubs.

AP

DETROIT (AP) — In the big picture, the Detroit Tigers are helping themselves with a bad finish to a terrible season.

Edwin Jackson allowed five runs in five innings, and the Tigers took control of the race for the top pick in next June's amateur draft with an 8-2 loss to the Baltimore Orioles on Sunday.

Tigers manager Ron Gardenhire isn't looking at the grand scheme,

"This is a young, tired baseball team that has played a lot of games without much time off, and we've got a few more days before we get a day off," Gardenhire said. "That's not an excuse, though. We didn't play well today. We need to be better tomorrow."

Detroit (44-104) has lost two of the first three games of the four-game series against the Orioles (49-100), opening a 4½-game advantage for the worst record in the major leagues. Any combination of 10 Tigers losses and Orioles wins would clinch the top pick for Detroit in a draft highlighted by Arizona State first baseman Spencer Torkelson and Georgia pitcher Emerson Hancock.

FOLLOW THE MONEY: MLB player salaries and payrolls for every major league team

Baltimore took Oregon State catcher Adley Rutschman with the top pick this year after finishing 47-115 last season. Detroit selected Auburn pitcher Casey Mize with the No. 1 selection in 2018, a year after going 64-98.

Detroit trailed 6-2 before a 39-minute rain delay in the middle of the sixth inning.

"The game had no pace, with a lot of walks, and that means our guys are standing around in the field and losing their edge," Gardenhire said. "I think that got even worse after the rain."

Baltimore's bullpen took over after the delay, striking out nine in four scoreless innings.

"They did a really nice job, but we gave them a breather by adding on some runs," Orioles manager Brandon Hyde said. "That hasn't been one of our strong suits this season, so it was good to see."

Baltimore won a night after blowing leads in the ninth and 12th innings of an 8-4 defeat that ended with John Hicks' grand slam.

"I think we've done really well in bounce-back games," Rio Ruiz said. "It is huge to come back today and do what we did."

Jackson (3-10) gave up seven hits and two walks in five-plus innings, dropping to 0-6 with a 11.47 ERA in his last five starts.

Asher Wojciechowski (3-8) won for the first time since July 26, allowing two runs and eight hits in five innings. He had been 0-5 in his previous eight starts.

Trailing 2-1, the Orioles took the lead in a three-run third that included Dwight Smith Jr.'s two-out triple, Hanser Alberto's run-scoring bunt single and tiebreaking two-run homer by Ruiz. Baltimore broke open the game on two-run singles by Jonathan Villar off Nick Ramirez in the sixth and Anthony Santander against Matt Hall in the eighth. Santander stopped an 0-for-27 slide.

The game was delayed by rain for 39 minutes in the bottom of the sixth.

TIGERS CLOSE IN ON LOSS RECORD

Detroit is 20-54 at home with seven games left at Comerica Park. The big league record of 59 losses was by the 1939 St. Louis Browns.

HONORING CHACE NUMATA

All of the Tigers in the first inning walked to the plate to "Give It Up" by KC and the Sunshine Band in honor of Chace Numata. The catching prospect, who used that as his walk-up song with Double-A Erie, died on Sept. 2 after a skateboarding accident. His family donated his liver, pancreas, heart and both kidneys to patients in need.

UP NEXT

Baltimore LHP John Means (10-10, 3.47) and Detroit LHP Tyler Alexander (0-3, 5.40) are slated to start Monday's series finale. "This is a weird feeling," Hyde said. "I thought maybe tomorrow was a holiday or something, because staying on a Sunday night and playing at 4 on Monday afternoon is definitely different."

search_result.title: Rebuild America: The status of sports in returning in Indiana
search_result.text:
Many decisions by sports leaders about what to do during the pandemic are being made for them. Government, scientists and data analysts are in charge, not commissioners and athletic directors.

But as sports begin stirring in Indiana, here is where we are:

Motor sports

Racing features the most imminent start date. Gov. Eric Holcomb’s targeted date of phase 5 for getting the state “Back on Track” is July 4.

That is the scheduled day of IndyCar’s GMR Grand Prix and the NASCAR Xfinity series’ Pennzoil 150, both at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. The next day is supposed to be the Brickyard 400.

What you can expect from IndyStar:Rebuilding Indiana is part of our mission, from the newsroom to advertising

IMS president Doug Boles told IndyStar it is undetermined whether the races will be run with fans, “but at the same time, you can’t stop planning for all the scenarios,” he said. Boles said IMS is trying to “stay in lockstep” with the governor and Indianapolis Mayor Joe Hogsett.

The 104th Indianapolis 500 was postponed to Sunday, Aug. 23. The race is to be run outside the month of May for the first time since 1945.

Indianapolis Colts

The Colts began reopening their team facility on 56th Street on Tuesday (May 19). Headquarters had been closed since March 13.

Only players returning from injuries were to return. The NFL is not allowing teams to bring back coaches and players until all 32 may do so. The Colts are supposed to open training camp July 23 at Grand Park in Westfield.

The season opener is Sept. 13 at Jacksonville. The Colts’ first game at Lucas Oil Stadium is Sept. 20 against Minnesota.

Indiana Pacers

The Pacers might have played for the last time this season at Bankers Life Fieldhouse. Yet they might await playoff games, beginning in mid-July at Disney World.

The Pacers have begun admitting more players to the St. Vincent Center. Malcom Brogdon and Jeremy Lamb had already been there to rehabilitate injuries since the NBA suspended operations March 11. Victor Oladipo, who played in 13 games after returning from knee surgery, has been training in Orlando, Fla.

Oladipo might not have to relocate. The Athletic reported the NBA could resume the season in Orlando as a single site for all teams and games, perhaps going straight to playoffs.

The Pacers (39-26) would be seeded No. 5 and meet No. 4 seed Miami (41-24).

Colleges

There is more uneasiness about colleges than in any other segment of the sports world.

Will there be college football? If not, can that financial hit allow major colleges to afford any sports in 2020-21? If there is football, what about fans?

Purdue and Notre Dame are addressing COVID-19 by changing the academic calendar to an early August start, ending the semester by Thanksgiving and without a fall break. Late November coincides with the beginning of flu season, when coronavirus cases are expected to increase.

Venue owners eager to reopen, but unsure:Music venues band together to face challenges of coming back

Time to get out and go?What coronavirus means for your Indiana summer vacation

Indiana University and Butler have also announced they will bring back students to campus for fall classes.

Notre Dame is scheduled to open in football Aug. 29 against Navy at Dublin, Ireland, although a U.S. stadium is a possibility. One pandemic model includes an abbreviated conference-only schedule. Notre Dame is an independent in football but is affiliated with the Atlantic Coast Conference in other sports.

One pandemic model in basketball is for a conference-only season that doesn’t begin until January.

Other pro leagues

Pro sports leagues outside the major ones have more uncertainty. Will they have a season at all?

That applies to minor league baseball’s Indianapolis Indians, WNBA’s Indiana Fever and United Soccer League’s Indy Eleven.

The Indians’ season has been postponed until at least July 4, according to their website. Minor league baseball does not have television and radio contracts of those in the majors, so it is impractical to have games at Victory Field without fans.

The Fever were not going to play at Bankers Life Fieldhouse anyway. Renovations of their home arena meant a summer at Hinkle Fieldhouse.

'I hope I can succeed':How mom and pop shops will adapt to a changed world

Slow but stable?How coronavirus has affected Indianapolis home sales

NBA commissioner Cathy Englebert said she is optimistic about having a season, albeit with all teams at one site or a small number of sites. Scenarios for playing involved doing so without fans, Englebert said. She said it is unlikely NBA and WNBA teams would play in the same venues.

The Indy Eleven plan to play again at Lucas Oil Stadium, perhaps without fans. Starting the season depends on resolution of talks between the USL and players’ union.

High schools

Football, no? Cross-country and golf, yes?

The Indiana High School Athletic Association is allowing schools to reopen July 1 for summer workouts. But for fall sports to go on as scheduled, in-person classes must resume, and each county will look different. Each sport could be treated differently.
