search_result.title: Flu and other respiratory virus activity continues to ramp up across ...
search_result.text:
CNN —

Government health officials on Friday warned of an early and severe start to cold and flu season in the United States, saying they were closely monitoring hospital capacity and medical supplies and were ready to send help if needed.

“We suspect that many children are being exposed to some respiratory viruses now for the first time, having avoided these viruses during the height of the pandemic,” said Dr. Jose Romero, director of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases, said on a call with reporters.

Across the United States, cases of respiratory syncytial virus, or RSV, and influenza are increasing. At the same time, Covid-19 cases, which had been dropping, appear to have plateaued over the last three weeks, Romero said. Cases have flattened as a raft of new variants has been gaining ground against BA.5, the Omicron subvariant that caused a wave of illness over the summer.

The spikes in viral illnesses have already begun to strain hospitals.

Dawn O’Connell, assistant secretary for preparedness and response, said Friday that her agency was staying in close contact with health care systems and states.

“We are monitoring capacity across the country sharing best practices to reduce the strain on systems and standing by to deploy additional personnel and supplies as needed,” she said, noting that so far, no states have requested this help.

“There’s no doubt that we will face some challenges this winter,” O’Connell said.

Flu, RSV hitting early and hard

Seventeen states, Washington, DC, and New York City, are reporting high or very high respiratory illness activity amid a flu season that’s hitting harder and earlier than usual, according to data published Friday by the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Influenza activity continues to increase in the US – the number of flu illnesses, hospitalizations and deaths so far this season nearly doubled in the past week. The CDC now estimates that there have been at least 1.6 million illnesses, 13,000 hospitalizations and 730 deaths from influenza, including two reported deaths among children so far this season. About one in 11 tests for flu were positive last week.

“In fact, we’re seeing the highest influenza hospitalization rates going back a decade,” Romero said.

The last time flu hospitalization rates have been this high at this point in the season was during the H1N1 pandemic. The latest CDC update tracks data through October 29.

There’s no real mystery about why viral illnesses are on the upswing, said Dr. Michael Mina, who is an epidemiologist and chief science officer at eMed, a company offering telehealth test-to-treat services.

“We enjoyed the benefit of not having influenza for the last couple of years, primarily because of SARS-CoV-2. Extra mitigation measures like social distancing, masking, and not going out for roughly a year have only delayed the inevitable. Now that we have released the pressures put in place to keep viruses at bay and move into this first real flu season, we, unfortunately, feel its impact,” he said.

RSV cases are also increasing nationally, although there are regional differences in the circulation of these viruses, Romero said. It’s a common respiratory infection that typically causes mild, cold-like symptoms, but it can cause serious illness, particularly in older adults and infants.

In the South and Mountain West, RSV cases appear to have peaked in October. In those regions, RSV cases are falling, even as influenza is spiking.

Flu activity is highest in the South, followed by the Mid-Atlantic and parts of the West Coast. Data from Walgreens that tracks prescriptions for antiviral treatments – such as Tamiflu – suggest there are hotspots in Mississippi and Alabama, as well as the Gulf Coast area, including Houston and New Orleans.

RSV hospitalizations were also significantly higher than usual, according to another weekly update published by the CDC on Thursday.

Cumulative RSV hospitalization rates have already reached levels that are typically not seen until December in the US. They’re rising among all age groups, but especially among children.

About four out of every 1,000 babies under 6 months old have been hospitalized with RSV so far this season – just about a month in. More than two in every 1,000 babies between 6 months and one year have been hospitalized with RSV so far this season, as have more than one in every 1,000 children between age one and two.

Overall in the US, nearly one in five PCR tests for RSV were positive for the week ending October 29, nearly doubling over the course of the month.

Weekly cases counts are less complete for the most current weeks, but there have been more RSV cases detected by PCR tests each week in October 2022 than any other week in at least the past two years. Weekly case counts for the week ending October 22 were more than double any other week in 2020 or 2021.

There are signs that RSV cases are slowing in the southern region of the US, but test positivity rates and cases continue to rise in other regions, especially the Midwest.

And pediatric hospitals remain more full than average with RSV patients and other conditions. According to data from the US Department of Health and Human Services, more than three-quarters of pediatric hospital beds and pediatric ICU beds are currently in use nationwide, compared with an average of about two-thirds full over the past two years.

As of Friday, seventeen states have less than one in five beds available. Five of them are more than 90% full: Rhode Island, Arizona, Maine, Minnesota and Delaware, along with Washington, DC.

Vaccination is the best protection

Romero stressed that with holiday gatherings just around the corner, vaccination is the best protection against these infections.

“We have vaccines for two of the three viruses we talked about influenza, and COVID 19,” he said, and he urged Americans to take advantage of them, though not enough have.

According to the CDC’s data tracker, just 8.4% of eligible Americans have received a new updated Covid-19 booster.

Vaccinations are lower than usual for influenza, too. Based on data from insurance claims, adult flu vaccinations are down about 5 million compared to where they were last year at the same time, said Lynnette Brammer, who leads surveillance for the CDC’s influenza division.

For children, coverage looks about the same as last year, but those levels represent a 6% drop from what flu vaccinations in kids looked like before the pandemic, Brammer said.

Romero stressed that while most adults only need a single annual influenza vaccine, children who are being vaccinated against the flu for the first time need two shots.

He also advised people not to try to guess what they had based on their symptoms alone since many of these viruses can cause similar symptoms.

Get CNN Health's weekly newsletter Sign up here to get The Results Are In with Dr. Sanjay Gupta every Tuesday from the CNN Health team.

Going to the doctor for a test as as soon as you start to feel bad could help you take advantage of early antiviral treatments which are available for influenza and Covid-19.

Romero said the CDC was preparing to send doctors more information about who should qualify for these test-to-treat strategies.

In addition to vaccination, Romero reminded people to cover their coughs and sneezes, avoid other individuals who are sick, wash hands frequently and use alcohol-based hand sanitizers.

“People who also may also choose to wear a well-fitting mask as an added precaution,” Romero said.

search_result.title: NJ confirms 2 cases of new more contagious COVID strain in state
search_result.text:
New Jersey has confirmed its first two cases of a mutation of the coronavirus first identified in the United Kingdom, the state Health Commissioner said Friday.

The virus variant is much more contagious than the coronavirus strain that has killed more than 400,000 Americans, but current vaccines appear to be effective against it. However, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said Friday that the variant may be more deadly.

"Today we are reporting that two confirmed COVID-19 variant cases involving the B.1.1.7 or U.K. variant have been identified in New Jersey," state Health Commissioner Judith Persichilli said.

The two cases involved an Ocean County man in his 60s, who recovered without being hospitalized, and a child who traveled to northern New Jersey and never had symptoms, she said.

Persichilli said there was "no evidence that infection by this variant causes more severe disease," citing reports from the federal Centers for Disease Control. But she spoke before reports Friday afternoon from London that the strain detected there in September may cause up to 30% more deaths.

If the previous strain caused 10 deaths per 1,000 cases among 60-year-olds, the variant appears to cause 13 or 14 deaths, according to Johnson's chief scientific adviser, who stressed that "there's a lot of uncertainty around these numbers."

Potential 'game-changer':Hopes high for Johnson & Johnson COVID vaccine if authorized

Vaccine:Here's where to get COVID-19 vaccinations in New Jersey, but supplies are scarce

Confirmation that the U.K. variant is present in New Jersey had been expected, with every neighboring state except Delaware reporting cases. More than 20 states have confirmed such cases as of Friday.

The Ocean County man developed symptoms on Dec. 29 and was tested on Jan. 6, Perischilli said. He had no history of travel or known exposure to a person who was sick with COVID-19. When the sample collected for his PCR test showed results that suggested the variant might be present, it was sent to another lab for a complete genomic analysis.

The child, who had stayed in New Jersey, was tested Jan. 11 in New York City, and was asymptomatic. The Health Department's communicable disease service is continuing to investigate the two cases, Persichilli said.

The arrival of the virus variant during a frustratingly slow vaccine rollout in New Jersey and the United States added to the mounting impatience among those waiting for the shots. An increase in the number of patients needing hospital care would strain the health care system.

The number of people with the newly identified mutation is "only going to go up," Gov. Phil Murphy said. "Clearly the faster we can get folks vaccinated, the better," he said Wednesday.

Story continues after chart

"It's kind of a race between getting as many people vaccinated versus the virus itself replicating and becoming the dominant strain," Dr. Eddy Bresnitz, a former state epidemiologist who is leading the Health Department's professional advisory committee, said earlier this week.

100-mile drive, hours in the cold:Here's what New Jerseyans are doing to get a COVID shot

Bumpy rollout:As millions compete for shots, New Jersey seniors struggle with online COVID vaccine system

The new variant is estimated to be 30% to 70% more transmissible than the current strain. That means that if the current strain infects 10 of 100 people, the new strain will infect 13 to 17 of 100. It is likely to become dominant in the United States by March, according to the CDC's predictive models.

Recent genomic analysis of the virus infecting 1,000 patients in the Hackensack Meridian Health system did not turn up evidence of the U.K. virus mutation, said Dr. David Perlin, the chief scientific officer for the system's Center for Discovery and Innovation. Analysis of an additional 1,000 samples was underway Friday, he said.

This "just heightens the need to wear masks, socially distance, and do all the things we’ve been trying to do in terms of prevention of transmission and infection control," he said.

New York State first reported a confirmed case of the variant on Jan. 4, and academic laboratories in New Jersey have been on high alert for the mutation. But only a tiny fraction of the 4,000 to 5,000 COVID-positive test samples collected each day are submitted for a full genomic analysis.

The state public health laboratory has been screening some samples and sending them to the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta to see if they contain the mutation, a spokeswoman said earlier this month. The lab in New Jersey expected to develop the ability to do genomic testing of viral samples soon, she said.

As viruses replicate billions of times in a pandemic, they develop slight variations in their genetic code, a process known as genetic drift. Some of the variations are insignificant, but others may cause changes in the way the virus binds with human cells or acts in the human body.

ALBANY - New York on Monday confirmed its first case of a new coronavirus strain that has swept through the United Kingdom.

A man in his 60s who is associated with a jewelry store in Saratoga Springs, north of Albany, was confirmed to have the new, more contagious variant of the virus, known as B.1.1.7, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said Monday.

The man has been suffering from symptoms from the virus, but is recovering, Cuomo said. Still, the governor warned that people who visited the store, N. Fox Jewelers at 404 Broadway, to get tested and contact the state if they have symptoms if they visited the store between Dec. 18 and Dec. 24.

If you've been there, "you should contact us and get a test immediately," Cuomo said. He said the man had not been traveling.

"He did not travel recently so that suggests it was in the community," Cuomo said. "It was community spread rather than traveling to the U.K."

Cuomo said the new strain found in New York comes after about 5,000 tests have been done in New York specifically looking for it. This is the first one to come back positive.

The governor said while it's not surprising the state now has a case, it is a concern: New York's positivity rate is at its highest level since the spring and this strain is more contagious.

At least three U.S. states and 33 countries have identified the new variant, and there is also another strain that several countries have found.

Cuomo said several other workers at the jewelry store have COVID-19, but it is unclear yet whether they also have the new strain.

Cuomo said the store had been closed since Christmas Eve.

"The safety and confidence of our employees and customers have always been of the utmost importance to us so we feel that this is the correct step for us to take," the store said of closing through Jan. 3 on its Facebook page.

"We apologize in advance if you were planning on visiting us this week. Our highest priority is the health and safety of our community."

The strain was first spotted in September in southeastern England and accounted for a quarter of cases in London by November. By the week of Dec. 9, it was responsible for 60% of cases in the city.

"It’s able to bind to the receptors on cells better, and therefore is transmitted better," Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation's leading infectious disease expert, said last month.
